Technical Details

Michael Dumelle, Matt Higham, and Jay M. Ver Hoef

Source: vignettes/articles/technical.Rmd
technical.Rmd

Introduction

This vignette covers technical details regarding the functions in that perform computations in spmodel. We first provide a notation guide and then describe relevant details for each function.

If you use spmodel in a formal publication or report, please cite it. Citing spmodel lets us devote more resources to it in the future. To view the spmodel citation, run

citation(package = "spmodel")
#> To cite spmodel in publications use:
#> 
#>   Dumelle M, Higham M, Ver Hoef JM (2023). spmodel: Spatial statistical
#>   modeling and prediction in R. PLOS ONE 18(3): e0282524.
#>   https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0282524
#> 
#> A BibTeX entry for LaTeX users is
#> 
#>   @Article{,
#>     title = {{spmodel}: Spatial statistical modeling and prediction in {R}},
#>     author = {Michael Dumelle and Matt Higham and Jay M. {Ver Hoef}},
#>     journal = {PLOS ONE},
#>     year = {2023},
#>     volume = {18},
#>     number = {3},
#>     pages = {1--32},
#>     doi = {10.1371/journal.pone.0282524},
#>     url = {https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0282524},
#>   }

A hat indicates the parameters are estimated (i.e., ğ›ƒÌ‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}) or evaluated at a relevant estimated parameter vector (e.g., ğšºÌ‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}} is evaluated at ğ›‰Ì‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}). When â„“(ğš¯Ì‚)\ell(\boldsymbol{\hat{\Theta}}) is written, it means the log-likelihood evaluated at its maximum, ğš¯Ì‚\boldsymbol{\hat{\Theta}}. When the covariance matrix of ğ€\mathbf{A} is ğšº\boldsymbol{\Sigma}, we say ğ€*\mathbf{A}^* â€œwhitensâ€ ğ€\mathbf{A} because Cov(ğ€*)=Cov(ğšºâˆ’1/2ğ€)=ğšºâˆ’1/2Cov(ğ€)ğšºâˆ’1/2=ğšºâˆ’1/2ğšºğšºâˆ’1/2=(ğšºâˆ’1/2ğšº1/2)(ğšº1/2ğšºâˆ’1/2)=ğˆ.\begin{equation*} \text{Cov}(\mathbf{A}^*) = \text{Cov}(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2}\mathbf{A}) = \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2}\text{Cov}(\mathbf{A})\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2} = \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2}\boldsymbol{\Sigma} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2} = (\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1/2})(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1/2}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2}) = \mathbf{I}. \end{equation*} Later we discuss how to obtain ğšº1/2\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1/2}.

Spatial Linear Models

Statistical linear models are often parameterized as ğ²=ğ—ğ›ƒ+ğ›œ,\begin{equation}\label{eq:lm} \mathbf{y} = \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\beta} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon}, \end{equation} where for a sample size nn, ğ²\mathbf{y} is an nÃ—1n \times 1 column vector of response variables, ğ—\mathbf{X} is an nÃ—pn \times p design (model) matrix of explanatory variables, ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta} is a pÃ—1p \times 1 column vector of fixed effects controlling the impact of ğ—\mathbf{X} on ğ²\mathbf{y}, and ğ›œ\boldsymbol{\epsilon} is an nÃ—1n \times 1 column vector of random errors. We typically assume that E(ğ›œ)=ğŸ\text{E}(\boldsymbol{\epsilon}) = \mathbf{0} and Cov(ğ›œ)=ÏƒÏµ2ğˆ\text{Cov}(\boldsymbol{\epsilon}) = \sigma^2_\epsilon \mathbf{I}, where E(â‹…)\text{E}(\cdot) denotes expectation, Cov(â‹…)\text{Cov}(\cdot) denotes covariance, ÏƒÏµ2\sigma^2_\epsilon denotes a variance parameter, and ğˆ\mathbf{I} denotes the identity matrix.

The model ğ²=ğ—ğ›ƒ+ğ›œ\mathbf{y} = \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\beta} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon} assumes the elements of ğ²\mathbf{y} are uncorrelated. Typically for spatial data, elements of ğ²\mathbf{y} are correlated, as observations close together in space tend to be more similar than observations far apart (Tobler 1970). Failing to properly accommodate the spatial dependence in ğ²\mathbf{y} can cause researchers to draw incorrect conclusions about their data. To accommodate spatial dependence in ğ²\mathbf{y}, an nÃ—1n \times 1 spatial random effect, ğ›•\boldsymbol{\tau}, is added to the linear model, yielding the model ğ²=ğ—ğ›ƒ+ğ›•+ğ›œ,\begin{equation}\label{eq:splm} \mathbf{y} = \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\beta} + \boldsymbol{\tau} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon}, \end{equation} where ğ›•\boldsymbol{\tau} is independent of ğ›œ\boldsymbol{\epsilon}, E(ğ›•)=ğŸ\text{E}(\boldsymbol{\tau}) = \mathbf{0}, Cov(ğ›•)=ÏƒÏ„2ğ‘\text{Cov}(\boldsymbol{\tau}) = \sigma^2_\tau \mathbf{R}, ğ‘\mathbf{R} is a matrix that determines the spatial dependence structure in ğ²\mathbf{y} and depends on a range parameter, Ï•\phi. We discuss ğ‘\mathbf{R} in more detail shortly. The parameter ÏƒÏ„2\sigma^2_\tau is called the spatially dependent random error variance or partial sill. The parameter ÏƒÏµ2\sigma^2_\epsilon is called the spatially independent random error variance or nugget. These two variance parameters are henceforth more intuitively written as Ïƒde2\sigma^2_{de} and Ïƒie2\sigma^2_{ie}, respectively. The covariance of ğ²\mathbf{y} is denoted ğšº\boldsymbol{\Sigma} and given by Ïƒde2ğ‘+Ïƒie2ğˆ\sigma^2_{de} \mathbf{R} + \sigma^2_{ie} \mathbf{I}. The parameters that compose this covariance are contained in the vector ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta}, which is called the covariance parameter vector.

The model ğ²=ğ—ğ›ƒ+ğ›•+ğ›œ\mathbf{y} = \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\beta} + \boldsymbol{\tau} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon} is called the spatial linear model. The spatial linear model applies to both point-referenced and areal (i.e., lattice) data. Spatial data are point-referenced when the elements in ğ²\mathbf{y} are observed at point-locations indexed by x-coordinates and y-coordinates on a spatially continuous surface with an infinite number of locations. The splm() function is used to fit spatial linear models for point-referenced data (these are sometimes called geostatistical models). One spatial covariance function available in splm() is the exponential spatial covariance function, which has an ğ‘\mathbf{R} matrix given by ğ‘=exp(âˆ’ğŒ/Ï•),\begin{equation*} \mathbf{R} = \exp(-\mathbf{M} / \phi), \end{equation*}
where ğŒ\mathbf{M} is a matrix of Euclidean distances among observations. Recall that Ï•\phi is the range parameter, controlling the behavior of of the covariance function as a function of distance. Parameterizations for splm() spatial covariance types and their ğ‘\mathbf{R} matrices can be seen by running help("splm", "spmodel") or vignette("technical", "spmodel"). Some of these spatial covariance types (e.g., MatÃ©rn) depend on an extra parameter beyond Ïƒde2\sigma^2_{de}, Ïƒie2\sigma^2_{ie}, and Ï•\phi.

Spatial data are areal when the elements in ğ²\mathbf{y} are observed as part of a finite network of polygons whose connections are indexed by a neighborhood structure. For example, the polygons may represent counties in a state that are neighbors if they share at least one boundary. Areal data are often equivalently called lattice data (Cressie 1993). The spautor() function is used to fit spatial linear models for areal data (these are sometimes called spatial autoregressive models). One spatial autoregressive covariance function available in spautor() is the simultaneous autoregressive spatial covariance function, which has an ğ‘\mathbf{R} matrix given by ğ‘=[(ğˆâˆ’Ï•ğ–)(ğˆâˆ’Ï•ğ–)âŠ¤]âˆ’1,\begin{equation*} \mathbf{R} = [(\mathbf{I} - \phi \mathbf{W})(\mathbf{I} - \phi \mathbf{W})^\top]^{-1}, \end{equation*} where ğ–\mathbf{W} is a weight matrix describing the neighborhood structure in ğ²\mathbf{y}. Parameterizations for spautor() spatial covariance types and their ğ‘\mathbf{R} matrices can be seen by running help("spautor", "spmodel") or vignette("technical", "spmodel").

One way to define ğ–\mathbf{W} is through queen contiguity (Anselin, Syabri, and Kho 2010). Two observations are queen contiguous if they share a boundary. The ijijth element of ğ–\mathbf{W} is then one if observation ii and observation jj are queen contiguous and zero otherwise. Observations are not considered neighbors with themselves, so each diagonal element of ğ–\mathbf{W} is zero.

Sometimes each element in the weight matrix ğ–\mathbf{W} is divided by its respective row sum. This is called row-standardization. Row-standardizing ğ–\mathbf{W} has several benefits, which are discussed in detail by Ver Hoef et al. (2018).

AIC() and AICc()

The AIC() and AICc() functions in spmodel are defined for restricted maximum likelihood and maximum likelihood estimation, which maximize a likelihood. The AIC and AICc as defined by Hoeting et al. (2006) are given by AIC=âˆ’2â„“(ğš¯Ì‚)+2(|ğš¯Ì‚|)AICc=âˆ’2â„“(ğš¯Ì‚)+2n(|ğš¯Ì‚|)/(nâˆ’|ğš¯Ì‚|âˆ’1),\begin{equation*}\label{eq:sp_aic} \begin{split} \text{AIC} & = -2\ell(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Theta}}) + 2(|\hat{\boldsymbol{\Theta}}|) \\ \text{AICc} & = -2\ell(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Theta}}) + 2n(|\hat{\boldsymbol{\Theta}}|) / (n - |\hat{\boldsymbol{\Theta}}| - 1), \end{split} \end{equation*} where |ğš¯Ì‚||\hat{\boldsymbol{\Theta}}| is the cardinality of ğš¯Ì‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\Theta}}. For restricted maximum likelihood, ğš¯Ì‚â‰¡{ğ›‰Ì‚}\hat{\boldsymbol{\Theta}} \equiv \{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\}. For maximum likelihood, ğš¯Ì‚â‰¡{ğ›‰Ì‚,ğ›ƒÌ‚}\hat{\boldsymbol{\Theta}} \equiv \{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}\} The discrepancy arises because restricted maximum likelihood integrates the fixed effects out of the likelihood, and so the likelihood does not depend on ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta}.

AIC comparisons between a model fit using restricted maximum likelihood and a model fit using maximum likelihood are meaningless, as the models are fit with different likelihoods. AIC comparisons between models fit using restricted maximum likelihood are only valid when the models have the same fixed effect structure. In contrast, AIC comparisons between models fit using maximum likelihood are valid when the models have different fixed effect structures.

anova()

Test statistics from are formed using the general linear hypothesis test. Let ğ‹\mathbf{L} be an lÃ—pl \times p contrast matrix and l0l_0 be an lÃ—1l \times 1 vector. The null hypothesis is that ğ‹ğ›ƒÌ‚=l0\mathbf{L} \boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}} = l_0 and the alternative hypothesis is that ğ‹ğ›ƒÌ‚â‰ l0\mathbf{L} \boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}} \neq l_0. Usually, l0l_0 is the zero vector (in spmodel, this is assumed). The test statistic is denoted Chi2Chi2 and is given by Chi2=[(ğ‹ğ›ƒÌ‚âˆ’l0)âŠ¤(ğ‹(ğ—âŠ¤ğšºÌ‚ğ—)âˆ’1ğ‹âŠ¤)âˆ’1(ğ‹ğ›ƒÌ‚âˆ’l0)]\begin{equation*}\label{eq:glht} Chi2 = [(\mathbf{L} \boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}} - l_0)^\top(\mathbf{L} (\mathbf{X}^\top \mathbf{\hat{\Sigma}} \mathbf{X})^{-1} \mathbf{L}^\top)^{-1}(\mathbf{L} \boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}} - l_0)] \end{equation*} By default, ğ‹\mathbf{L} is chosen such that each variable in the data used to fit the model is tested marginally (i.e., controlling for the other variables) against l0=ğŸl_0 = \mathbf{0}. If this default is not desired, the and arguments can be used to pass user-defined ğ‹\mathbf{L} matrices to . They must be constructed in such a way that l0=ğŸl_0 = \mathbf{0}.

It is notoriously difficult to determine appropriate p-values for linear mixed models based on the general linear hypothesis test. lme4, for example, does not report p-values by default. A few reasons why obtaining p-values is so challenging:

  • The first (and often most important) challenge is that when estimating ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta} using a finite sample, it is usually not clear what the null distribution of Chi2Chi2 is. In certain cases such as ordinary least squares regression or some experimental designs (e.g., blocked design, split plot design, etc.), Chi2/rank(ğ‹)Chi2 / rank(\mathbf{L}) is F-distributed with known numerator and denominator degrees of freedom. But outside of these well-studied cases, no general results exist.
  • The second challenge is that the standard error of Chi2Chi2 does not account for the uncertainty in ğ›‰Ì‚\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}. For some approaches to addressing this problem, see Kackar and Harville (1984), Prasad and Rao (1990), Harville and Jeske (1992), and Kenward and Roger (1997).
  • The third challenge is in determining denominator degrees of freedom. Again, in some cases, these are known â€“ but this is not true in general. For some approaches to addressing this problem, see Satterthwaite (1946), Schluchter and Elashoff (1990), Hrong-Tai Fai and Cornelius (1996), Kenward and Roger (1997), Littell et al. (2006), Pinheiro and Bates (2006), and Kenward and Roger (2009).

For these reasons, spmodel uses an asymptotic (i.e., large sample) Chi-squared test when calculating p-values using anova(). This approach addresses the three points above by assuming that with a large enough sample size:

  • Chi2Chi2 is asymptotically Chi-squared (under certain conditions) with rank(ğ‹)rank(\mathbf{L}) degrees of freedom when the null hypothesis is true.
  • The uncertainty from estimating ğ›‰Ì‚\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}} is small enough to be safely ignored.

Because the approximation is asymptotic, degree of freedom adjustments can be ignored (it is also worth noting that an F distribution with infinite denominator degrees of freedom is a Chi-squared distribution scaled by rank(ğ‹)rank(\mathbf{L}). This asymptotic approximation implies these p-values are likely unreliable with small samples.

Note that when comparing full and reduced models, the general linear hypothesis test is analogous to an extra sum of (whitened) squares approach (Myers et al. 2012).

A second approach to determining p-values is a likelihood ratio test. Let â„“(ğš¯Ì‚)\ell(\boldsymbol{\hat{\Theta}}) be the log-likelihood for some full model and â„“(ğš¯Ì‚0)\ell(\boldsymbol{\hat{\Theta}}_0) be the log-likelihood for some reduced model. For the likelihood ratio test to be valid, the reduced model must be nested in the full model, which means that â„“(ğš¯Ì‚0)\ell(\boldsymbol{\hat{\Theta}}_0) is obtained by fixing some parameters in ğš¯\boldsymbol{\Theta}. When the likelihood ratio test is valid, X2=2â„“(ğš¯Ì‚)âˆ’2â„“(ğš¯Ì‚0)X^2 = 2\ell(\boldsymbol{\hat{\Theta}}) - 2\ell(\boldsymbol{\hat{\Theta}}_0) is asymptotically Chi-squared with degrees of freedom equal to the difference in estimated parameters between the full and reduced models.

For restricted maximum likelihood estimation, likelihood ratio tests can only be used to compare nested models with the same explanatory variables. To use likelihood ratio tests for comparing different explanatory variable structures, parameters must be estimated using maximum likelihood estimation. When using likelihood ratio tests to assess the importance of parameters on the boundary of a parameter space (e.g., a variance parameter being zero), p-values tend to be too large (Self and Liang 1987; Stram and Lee 1994; Goldman and Whelan 2000; Pinheiro and Bates 2006).

BIC()

The BIC() function in spmodel is defined for restricted maximum likelihood and maximum likelihood estimation, which maximize a likelihood. The BIC as defined by Schwarz (1978) is given by $$\begin{equation*}\label{eq:sp_aic} \text{BIC} & = -2\ell(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Theta}}) + \ln(n)(|\hat{\boldsymbol{\Theta}}|) \\ \end{equation*}$$ where nn is the sample size and |ğš¯Ì‚||\hat{\boldsymbol{\Theta}}| is the cardinality of ğš¯Ì‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\Theta}}. For restricted maximum likelihood, ğš¯Ì‚â‰¡{ğ›‰Ì‚}\hat{\boldsymbol{\Theta}} \equiv \{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\}. For maximum likelihood, ğš¯Ì‚â‰¡{ğ›‰Ì‚,ğ›ƒÌ‚}\hat{\boldsymbol{\Theta}} \equiv \{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}\} The discrepancy arises because restricted maximum likelihood integrates the fixed effects out of the likelihood, and so the likelihood does not depend on ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta}.

BIC comparisons between a model fit using restricted maximum likelihood and a model fit using maximum likelihood are meaningless, as the models are fit with different likelihoods. BIC comparisons between models fit using restricted maximum likelihood are only valid when the models have the same fixed effect structure. In contrast, BIC comparisons between models fit using maximum likelihood are valid when the models have different fixed effect structures. While BIC was derived by Schwarz (1978) for independent data, Zimmerman and Ver Hoef (2024) show it can be useful for spatially-dependent data as well.

coef()

coef() returns relevant coefficients based on the type argument. When type = "fixed" (the default), coef() returns ğ›ƒÌ‚=(ğ—âŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1ğ—)âˆ’1ğ—âŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1ğ².\begin{equation*} \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}} = (\mathbf{X}^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1} \mathbf{X})^{-1}\mathbf{X}^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1} \mathbf{y} . \end{equation*} If the estimation method is restricted maximum likelihood or maximum likelihood, ğ›ƒÌ‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}} is known as the restricted maximum likelihood or maximum likelihood estimator of ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta}. If the estimation method is semivariogram weighted least squares or semivariogram composite likelihood, ğ›ƒÌ‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}} is known as the empirical generalized least squares estimator of ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta}. When type = "spcov", the estimated spatial covariance parameters are returned (available for all estimation methods). When type = "randcov", the estimated random effect variance parameters are returned (available for restricted maximum likelihood and maximum likelihood estimation).

confint()

confint() returns confidence intervals for estimated parameters. Currently, confint() only returns confidence intervals for ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta}. The (1âˆ’Î±)(1 - \alpha)% confidence interval for Î²i\beta_i is Î²Ì‚iÂ±z*(ğ—âŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1ğ—)i,iâˆ’1,\begin{equation*} \hat{\beta}_i \pm z^* \sqrt{(\mathbf{X}^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1} \mathbf{X})^{-1}_{i, i}}, \end{equation*} where (ğ—âŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1ğ—)i,iâˆ’1(\mathbf{X}^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1} \mathbf{X})^{-1}_{i, i} is the iith diagonal element in (ğ—âŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1ğ—)âˆ’1(\mathbf{X}^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1} \mathbf{X})^{-1}, Î¦(z*)=1âˆ’Î±/2\Phi(z^*) = 1 - \alpha / 2, Î¦(â‹…)\Phi(\cdot) is the standard normal (Gaussian) cumulative distribution function, and Î±=1âˆ’\alpha = 1 -level, where level is an argument to confint(). The default for level is 0.95, which corresponds to a z*z^* of approximately 1.96.

cooks.distance()

Cookâ€™s distance measures the influence of an observation (Cook 1979; Cook and Weisberg 1982). An influential observation has a large impact on the model fit. The vector of Cookâ€™s distances for the spatial linear model is given by ğp2pâŠ™diag(ğ‡s)âŠ™11âˆ’diag(ğ‡s),\begin{equation} \label{eq:cooksd} \frac{\mathbf{e}_p^2}{p} \odot diag(\mathbf{H}_s) \odot \frac{1}{1 - diag(\mathbf{H}_s)}, \end{equation} where ğp\mathbf{e}_p are the Pearson residuals and diag(ğ‡s)diag(\mathbf{H}_s) is the diagonal of the spatial hat matrix, ğ‡sâ‰¡ğ—*(ğ—*âŠ¤ğ—*)âˆ’1ğ—*âŠ¤\mathbf{H}_s \equiv \mathbf{X}^* (\mathbf{X}^{* \top} \mathbf{X}^*)^{-1} \mathbf{X}^{* \top}(Montgomery, Peck, and Vining 2021), and âŠ™\odot denotes the Hadmard (element-wise) product. The larger the Cookâ€™s distance, the larger the influence.

To better understand the previous form, recall that the the non-spatial linear model ğ²=ğ—ğ›ƒ+ğ›œ\mathbf{y} = \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\beta} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon} assumes elements of ğ›œ\boldsymbol{\epsilon} are independent and identically distributed (iid) with constant variance. In this context the vector of non-spatial Cookâ€™s distances is given by ğp2pâŠ™diag(ğ‡)âŠ™11âˆ’diag(ğ‡),\begin{equation*} \frac{\mathbf{e}_p^2}{p} \odot diag(\mathbf{H}) \odot \frac{1}{1 - diag(\mathbf{H})}, \end{equation*} where diag(ğ‡)diag(\mathbf{H}) is the diagonal of the non-spatial hat matrix, ğ‡â‰¡ğ—(ğ—âŠ¤ğ—)âˆ’1ğ—âŠ¤\mathbf{H} \equiv \mathbf{X} (\mathbf{X}^{\top} \mathbf{X})^{-1} \mathbf{X}^{\top}. When the elements of ğ›œ\boldsymbol{\epsilon} are not iid or do not have constant variance or both, the spatial Cookâ€™s distance cannot be calculated using ğ‡\mathbf{H}. First the linear model must be whitened according to ğ²*=ğ—*ğ›ƒ+ğ›œ*\mathbf{y}^* = \mathbf{X}^* \boldsymbol{\beta} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^*, where ğ›œ*\boldsymbol{\epsilon}^* is the whitened version of the sum of all random errors in the model. Then the spatial Cookâ€™s distance follows using ğ—*\mathbf{X}^*, the whitened version of ğ—\mathbf{X}.

deviance()

The deviance of a fitted model is ğ’Ÿğš¯=2â„“(ğš¯s)âˆ’2â„“(ğš¯Ì‚),\begin{equation*} \mathcal{D}_{\boldsymbol{\Theta}} = 2\ell(\boldsymbol{\Theta}_s) - 2\ell(\boldsymbol{\hat{\Theta}}), \end{equation*} where â„“(ğš¯s)\ell(\boldsymbol{\Theta}_s) is the log-likelihood of a â€œsaturatedâ€ model that fits every observation perfectly. For normal (Gaussian) random errors, ğ’Ÿğš¯=(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌ‚)âŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌ‚)\begin{equation*} \mathcal{D}_{\boldsymbol{\Theta}} = (\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}})^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1} (\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}) \end{equation*}

fitted()

Fitted values can be obtained for the response, spatial random errors, and random effects. The fitted values for the response (type = "response"), denoted ğ²Ì‚\mathbf{\hat{y}}, are given by ğ²Ì‚=ğ—ğ›ƒÌ‚.\begin{equation*}\label{eq:fit_resp} \mathbf{\hat{y}} = \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}} . \end{equation*} They are the estimated mean response given the set of explanatory variables for each observation.

Fitted values for spatial random errors (type = "spcov") and random effects (type = "randcov") are linked to best linear unbiased predictors from linear mixed model theory. Consider the standard random effects parameterization ğ²=ğ—ğ›ƒ+ğ™ğ®+ğ›œ,\begin{equation*} \mathbf{y} = \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\beta} + \mathbf{Z} \mathbf{u} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon}, \end{equation*} where ğ™\mathbf{Z} denotes the random effects design matrix, ğ®\mathbf{u} denotes the random effects, and ğ›œ\boldsymbol{\epsilon} denotes independent random error. Henderson (1975) states that the best linear unbiased predictor (BLUP) of a single random effect vector ğ®\mathbf{u}, denoted ğ®Ì‚\mathbf{\hat{u}}, is given by ğ®Ì‚=Ïƒu2ğ™âŠ¤ğšºâˆ’1(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌ‚),\begin{equation}\label{eq:blup_mm} \mathbf{\hat{u}} = \sigma^2_u \mathbf{Z}^\top \mathbf{\Sigma}^{-1}(\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}), \end{equation} where Ïƒu2\sigma^2_u is the variance of ğ®\mathbf{u}.

Searle, Casella, and McCulloch (2009) generalize this idea by showing that for a random vector ğ›‚\boldsymbol{\alpha} in a linear model, the best linear unbiased predictor (based on the response, ğ²\mathbf{y}) of ğ›‚\boldsymbol{\alpha}, denoted ğ›‚Ì‚\boldsymbol{\hat{\alpha}}, is given by ğ›‚Ì‚=E(ğ›‚)+ğšºÎ±ğšºâˆ’1(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌ‚),\begin{equation}\label{eq:blup_gen} \boldsymbol{\hat{\alpha}} = \text{E}(\boldsymbol{\alpha}) + \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_\alpha \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1}(\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}), \end{equation} where ğšºÎ±=Cov(ğ›‚,ğ²)\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_\alpha = \text{Cov}(\boldsymbol{\alpha}, \mathbf{y}). Evaluating this equation at the plug-in (empirical) estimates of the covariance parameters yields the empirical best linear unbiased predictor (EBLUP) of ğ›‚\boldsymbol{\alpha}.

Recall that the spatial linear model with random effects is ğ²=ğ—ğ›ƒ+ğ™ğ®+ğ›•+ğ›œ,\begin{equation*} \mathbf{y} = \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\beta} + \mathbf{Z} \mathbf{u} + \boldsymbol{\tau} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon}, \end{equation*} Building from previous results, we can find BLUPs for each random term in the spatial linear model (ğ®\mathbf{u}, ğ›•\boldsymbol{\tau}, and ğ›œ\boldsymbol{\epsilon}). For example, the BLUP of ğ®\mathbf{u} is found by noting that E(ğ®)=ğŸ\text{E}(\mathbf{u}) = \mathbf{0} and ğšºu=Cov(ğ®,ğ²)=Cov(ğ®,ğ—ğ›ƒ+ğ™ğ®+ğ›•+ğ›œ)=Cov(ğ®,ğ™ğ®)=Cov(ğ®,ğ®)ğ™âŠ¤=Ïƒu2ğ™âŠ¤,\begin{equation*} \mathbf{\Sigma}_u = \text{Cov}(\mathbf{u}, \mathbf{y}) = \text{Cov}(\mathbf{u}, \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\beta} + \mathbf{Z} \mathbf{u} + \boldsymbol{\tau} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon}) = \text{Cov}(\mathbf{u}, \mathbf{Z}\mathbf{u}) = \text{Cov}(\mathbf{u}, \mathbf{u})\mathbf{Z}^\top = \sigma^2_u \mathbf{Z}^\top, \end{equation*} where the result follows because the random terms in ğ²\mathbf{y} are independent and Cov(ğ®,ğ®)=Ïƒu2ğˆ\text{Cov}(\mathbf{u}, \mathbf{u}) = \sigma^2_u \mathbf{I}. Then it follows that ğ®Ì‚=E(ğ®)+ğšºuğšºâˆ’1(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌ‚)=Ïƒu2ğ™âŠ¤ğšºâˆ’1(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌ‚),\begin{equation*} \hat{\mathbf{u}} = \text{E}(\mathbf{u}) + \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_u \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1}(\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}) = \sigma^2_u \mathbf{Z}^\top \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1}(\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}), \end{equation*} which matches the previous form of the BLUP. Similarly, the BLUP of ğ›•\boldsymbol{\tau} is found by noting that E(ğ›•)=ğŸ\text{E}(\boldsymbol{\tau}) = \mathbf{0} and ğšºde=Cov(ğ›•,ğ²)=Cov(ğ›•,ğ—ğ›ƒ+ğ™ğ®+ğ›•+ğ›œ)=Cov(ğ›•,ğ›•)=Ïƒde2ğ‘,\begin{equation*} \mathbf{\Sigma}_{de} = \text{Cov}(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathbf{y}) = \text{Cov}(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\beta} + \mathbf{Z} \mathbf{u} + \boldsymbol{\tau} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon}) = \text{Cov}(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \boldsymbol{\tau}) = \sigma^2_{de} \mathbf{R}, \end{equation*} where the result follows because the random terms in ğ²\mathbf{y} are independent and Cov(ğ›•,ğ›•)=Ïƒde2ğ‘\text{Cov}(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \boldsymbol{\tau}) = \sigma^2_{de} \mathbf{R}, and Ïƒde2\sigma^2_{de} is the variance of ğ›•\boldsymbol{\tau}. Then it follows that ğ›•Ì‚=E(ğ›•)+ğšºdeğšºâˆ’1(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌ‚)=Ïƒde2ğ‘ğšºâˆ’1(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌ‚).\begin{equation}\label{eq:blup_sp} \hat{\boldsymbol{\tau}} = \text{E}(\boldsymbol{\tau}) + \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{de} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1}(\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}) = \sigma^2_{de} \mathbf{R} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1}(\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}). \end{equation} Fitted values for ğ›œ\boldsymbol{\epsilon} are obtained using similar arguments. Evaluating these equations at the plug-in (empirical) estimates of the covariance parameters yields EBLUPs.

When partition factors are used, the covariance matrix of all random effects (spatial and non-spatial) can be viewed as the interaction between the non-partitioned covariance matrix and the partition matrix, ğ\mathbf{P}. The ijijth entry in ğ\mathbf{P} equals one if observation ii and observation jj share the same level of the partition factor and zero otherwise. For spatial random effects, an adjustment is straightforward, as each column in ğšºde\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{de} corresponds to a distinct spatial random effect. Thus with partition factors, ğšºde*=ğšºdeâŠ™ğ=Ïƒde2ğ‘âŠ™ğ\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{de}^* = \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{de} \odot \mathbf{P} = \sigma^2_{de} \mathbf{R} \odot \mathbf{P}, where âŠ™\odot denotes the Hadmart (element-wise) product, is used instead of ğšºde\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{de}. Note that ğšºie\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{ie} is unchanged as it is proportional to the identity matrix. For non-spatial random effects, however, the situation is more complicated. Applying the BLUP formula directly yields BLUPs of random effects corresponding to the interaction between random effect levels and partition levels. Thus a logical approach is to average the non-zero BLUPs for each random effect level across partition levels, yielding a prediction for the random effect level. This does not imply, however, that these estimates are BLUPs of the random effect.

For big data without partition factors, the local indexes act as partition factors. That is, the BLUPs correspond to random effects interacted with each local index. For big data with partition factors, an adjusted partition factor is created as the interaction between each local index and the partition factor. Then this adjusted partition factor is applied to yield ğ›‚Ì‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}.

hatvalues()

Hat values measure the leverage of an observation. An observation has high leverage if its combination of explanatory variables is atypical (far from the mean explanatory vector). The spatial leverage (hat) matrix is given by ğ‡s=ğ—*(ğ—*âŠ¤ğ—*)âˆ’1ğ—*âŠ¤.\begin{equation} \label{eq:leverage} \mathbf{H}_s = \mathbf{X}^* (\mathbf{X}^{* \top} \mathbf{X}^*)^{-1} \mathbf{X}^{* \top}. \end{equation} The diagonal of this matrix yields the leverage (hat) values for each observation (Montgomery, Peck, and Vining 2021). The larger the hat value, the larger the leverage.

To better understand the previous form, recall that the the non-spatial linear model ğ²=ğ—ğ›ƒ+ğ›œ\mathbf{y} = \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\beta} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon} assumes elements of ğ›œ\boldsymbol{\epsilon} are independent and identically distributed (iid) with constant variance. In this context, the leverage (hat) matrix is given by ğ‡â‰¡ğ—(ğ—âŠ¤ğ—)âˆ’1ğ—âŠ¤,\begin{equation*} \mathbf{H} \equiv \mathbf{X} (\mathbf{X}^{\top} \mathbf{X})^{-1} \mathbf{X}^{\top}, \end{equation*} When the elements of ğ›œ\boldsymbol{\epsilon} are not iid or do not have constant variance or both, the spatial leverage (hat) matrix is not ğ‡\mathbf{H}. First the linear model must be whitened according to ğ²*=ğ—*ğ›ƒ+ğ›œ*\mathbf{y}^* = \mathbf{X}^* \boldsymbol{\beta} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^*, where ğ›œ*\boldsymbol{\epsilon}^* is the whitened version of the sum of all random errors in the model. Then the spatial leverage (hat) matrix follows using ğ—*\mathbf{X}^*, the whitened version of ğ—\mathbf{X}.

logLik()

The log-likelihood is given by â„“(ğš¯Ì‚)\ell(\boldsymbol{\hat{\Theta}}).

loocv()

kk-fold cross validation is a useful tool for evaluating model fits using â€œhold-outâ€ data. The data are split into kk sets. One-by-one, one of the kk sets is held out, the model is fit to the remaining kâˆ’1k - 1 sets, and predictions at each observation in the hold-out set are compared to their true values. The closer the predictions are to the true observations, the better the model fit. A special case where k=nk = n is known as leave-one-out cross validation (loocv), as each observation is left out one-by-one. Computationally efficient solutions exist for leave-one-out cross validation in the non-spatial linear model (with iid, constant variance errors). Outside of this case, however, fitting nn separate models can be computationally infeasible. loocv() makes a compromise that balances an approximation to the true solution with computational feasibility. First ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta} is estimated using all of the data. Then for each of the nn model fits, loocv() does not re-estimate ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta} but does re-estimate ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta}. This approach relies on the assumption that the covariance parameter estimates obtained using nâˆ’1n - 1 observations are approximately the same as the covariance parameter estimates obtained using all nn observations. For a large enough sample size, this is a reasonable assumption.

First define ğšºâˆ’i,âˆ’i\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{-i, -i} as ğšº\boldsymbol{\Sigma} with the iith row and column deleted, ğšºi,âˆ’i\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{i, -i} as the iith row of ğšº\boldsymbol{\Sigma} with the iith column deleted, ğšºi,i\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{i, i} as the iith diagonal element of ğšº\boldsymbol{\Sigma}, ğ—âˆ’i\mathbf{X}_{-i} as ğ—\mathbf{X} with the iith row deleted, ğ—i\mathbf{X}_{i} as the iith row of ğ—\mathbf{X}, yâˆ’iy_{-i} as ğ²\mathbf{y} with the iith element deleted, and ğ²i\mathbf{y}_i as the iith element of ğ²\mathbf{y}. Wolf (1978) shows that given ğšºâˆ’1\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1}, a computationally efficient form for ğšºâˆ’iâˆ’1\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1}_{-i} exists. First observe that ğšºâˆ’1\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1} can be represented blockwise as ğšºâˆ’1=[ğšºÌƒâˆ’i,âˆ’iğšºÌƒi,âˆ’iâŠ¤ğšºÌƒi,âˆ’iğšºÌƒi,i],\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{-i, -i} & \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{i,-i}^\top \\ \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{i,-i} & \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{i, i} \end{bmatrix}, \end{equation*} where the dimensions of each ğšºÌƒ\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}} match the respective dimensions of relevant blocks in ğšº\boldsymbol{\Sigma}. Then it follows that ğšºâˆ’i,âˆ’iâˆ’1=ğšºÌƒâˆ’i,âˆ’iâˆ’ğšºÌƒi,âˆ’iâŠ¤ğšºÌƒi,iâˆ’1ğšºÌƒi,âˆ’i\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1}_{-i, -i} = \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{-i, -i} - \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{i,-i}^\top \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{i, i}^{-1}\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{i,-i} \end{equation*} and ğ›ƒâˆ’i=(ğ—âˆ’iâŠ¤ğšºâˆ’i,âˆ’iâˆ’1ğ—âˆ’i)âˆ’1ğ—âˆ’iâŠ¤ğšºâˆ’i,âˆ’iâˆ’1ğ²âˆ’i,\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{\beta}_{-i} = (\mathbf{X}^\top_{-i} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1}_{-i, -i} \mathbf{X}_{-i})^{-1} \mathbf{X}^\top_{-i} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1}_{-i, -i} \mathbf{y}_{-i}, \end{equation*} where ğ›ƒi\boldsymbol{\beta}_i is the estimate of ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta} constructed without the iith observation.

The loocv prediction of yiy_i is then given by yÌ‚i=ğ—iğ›ƒÌ‚âˆ’i+ğšºÌ‚i,âˆ’iğšºÌ‚âˆ’i,âˆ’i(ğ²iâˆ’ğ—âˆ’iğ›ƒÌ‚âˆ’i)\begin{equation*} \hat{y}_i = \mathbf{X}_i \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{-i} + \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{i, -i}\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{-i, -i}(\mathbf{y}_i - \mathbf{X}_{-i} \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{-i}) \end{equation*} and the prediction variance of the loocv prediction of yiy_i is given by ÏƒÌ‡i2=ğšºÌ‚i,iâˆ’ğšºÌ‚i,âˆ’iğšºÌ‚âˆ’i,âˆ’iâˆ’1ğšºÌ‚i,âˆ’iâŠ¤+ği(ğ—âˆ’iâŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’i,âˆ’iâˆ’1ğ—âˆ’i)âˆ’1ğiâŠ¤,\begin{equation*} \dot{\sigma}^2_i = \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{i, i} - \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{i, - i} \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1}_{-i, -i} \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{i, - i}^\top + \mathbf{Q}_i(\mathbf{X}_{-i}^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{-i, -i}^{-1} \mathbf{X}_{-i})^{-1}\mathbf{Q}_i^\top , \end{equation*} where ği=ğ—iâˆ’ğšºÌ‚i,âˆ’iğšºÌ‚âˆ’i,âˆ’iâˆ’1ğ—âˆ’i\mathbf{Q}_i = \mathbf{X}_i - \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{i, -i} \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1}_{-i, -i} \mathbf{X}_{-i}. These formulas are analogous to the formulas used to obtain linear unbiased predictions of unobserved data and prediction variances. Model fits are evaluated using several statistics: bias, mean-squared-prediction error (MSPE), root-mean-squared-prediction error (RMSPE), and the squared correlation (cor2) between the observed data and leave-one-out predictions (regarded as a prediction version of r-squared appropriate for comparing across spatial and nonspatial models).

Bias is formally defined as bias=1nâˆ‘i=1n(yiâˆ’yÌ‚i).\begin{equation*} bias = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i = 1}^n(y_i - \hat{y}_i). \end{equation*}

MSPE is formally defined as MSPE=1nâˆ‘i=1n(yiâˆ’yÌ‚i)2.\begin{equation*} MSPE = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i = 1}^n(y_i - \hat{y}_i)^2. \end{equation*}

RMSPE is formally defined as RMSPE=1nâˆ‘i=1n(yiâˆ’yÌ‚i)2.\begin{equation*} RMSPE = \sqrt{\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i = 1}^n(y_i - \hat{y}_i)^2}. \end{equation*}

cor2 is formally defined as cor2=Cor(ğ²,ğ²Ì‚)2,\begin{equation*} cor2 = \text{Cor}(\mathbf{y}, \hat{\mathbf{y}})^2, \end{equation*} where Cor(â‹…)(\cdot) is the correlation function. cor2 is only returned for spatial linear models, as it is not applicable for spatial generalized linear models (we are predicting a latent mean parameter, which is unknown and not on the same scale as the original data).

Generally, bias should be near zero for well-fitting models. The lower the MSPE and RMSPE, the better the model fit. The higher the cor2, the better the model fit.

Big Data

Options for big data leave-one-out cross validation rely on the local argument, which is passed to predict(). The local list for predict() is explained in detail in the predict() section, but we provide a short summary of how local interacts with loocv() here.

For splm() and spautor() objects, the local method can be "all". When the local method is"all", all of the data are used for leave-one-out cross validation (i.e., it is implemented exactly as previously described). Parallelization is implemented when setting parallel = TRUE in local, and the number of cores to use for parallelization is specified via ncores.

For splm() objects, additional options for the local method are "covariance" and "distance". When the local method is "covariance", then a number of observations (specified via the size argument) having the highest covariance with the held-out observation are used in the local neighborhood prediction approach. When the local method is "distance", then a number of observations (specified via the size argument) closest to the held-out observation are used in the local neighborhood prediction approach. When no random effects are used, no partition factor is used, and the spatial covariance function is monotone decreasing, "covariance" and "distance" are equivalent. The local neighborhood approach only uses the observations in the local neighborhood of the held-out observation to perform prediction, and is thus an approximation to the true solution. Its computational efficiency derives from using ğšºl,l\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{l, l} (the covariance matrix of the observations in the local neighborhood) instead of ğšº\boldsymbol{\Sigma} (the covariance matrix of all the observations). Parallelization is implemented when setting parallel = TRUE in local, and the number of cores to use for parallelization is specified via ncores.

predict()

interval = "none"

The empirical best linear unbiased predictions (i.e., empirical Kriging predictor) of ğ²u\mathbf{y}_u are given by ğ²Ì‡u=ğ—uğ›ƒÌ‚+ğšºÌ‚uoğšºÌ‚oâˆ’1(ğ²oâˆ’ğ—oğ›ƒÌ‚).\begin{equation}\label{eq:blup} \mathbf{\dot{y}}_u = \mathbf{X}_u \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}} + \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{uo} \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1}_{o} (\mathbf{y}_o - \mathbf{X}_o \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}) . \end{equation}

This equation sometimes called an empirical universal Kriging predictor, a Kriging with external drift predictor, or a regression Kriging predictor.

The covariance matrix of ğ²Ì‡u\mathbf{\dot{y}}_uğšºÌ‡u=ğšºÌ‚uâˆ’ğšºÌ‚uoğšºÌ‚oâˆ’1ğšºÌ‚uoâŠ¤+ğ(ğ—oâŠ¤ğšºÌ‚oâˆ’1ğ—o)âˆ’1ğâŠ¤,\begin{equation}\label{eq:blup_cov} \dot{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_u = \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_u - \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{uo} \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1}_o \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^\top_{uo} + \mathbf{Q}(\mathbf{X}_o^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_o^{-1} \mathbf{X}_o)^{-1}\mathbf{Q}^\top , \end{equation} where ğ=ğ—uâˆ’ğšºÌ‚uoğšºÌ‚oâˆ’1ğ—o\mathbf{Q} = \mathbf{X}_u - \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{uo} \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1}_o \mathbf{X}_o.

When se.fit = TRUE, standard errors are returned by taking the square root of the diagonal of ğšºÌ‡u\dot{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_u.

interval = "prediction"

The empirical best linear unbiased predictions are returned as ğ²Ì‡u\mathbf{\dot{y}}_u. The (100 Ã—\timeslevel)% prediction interval for (yu)i(y_u)_i is (yÌ‡u)iÂ±z*(ğšºÌ‡u)i,i(\dot{y}_u)_i \pm z^* \sqrt{(\dot{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_u)_{i, i}}, where (ğšºÌ‡u)i,i\sqrt{(\dot{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_u)_{i, i}} is the standard error of (yÌ‡u)i(\dot{y}_u)_i obtained from se.fit = TRUE, Î¦(z*)=1âˆ’Î±/2\Phi(z^*) = 1 - \alpha / 2, Î¦(â‹…)\Phi(\cdot) is the standard normal (Gaussian) cumulative distribution function, Î±=1âˆ’\alpha = 1 -level, and level is an argument to predict(). The default for level is 0.95, which corresponds to a z*z^* of approximately 1.96.

interval = "confidence"

The best linear unbiased estimates of E[(yu)i]\text{E}[(y_u)_i] (E(â‹…)\text{E}(\cdot) denotes expectation) are returned by evaluating (ğ—u)iğ›ƒÌ‚(\mathbf{X}_u)_i \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, where (ğ—u)i(\mathbf{X}_u)_i is the iith row of ğ—u\mathbf{X}_u (i.e., fitted values corresponding to (ğ—u)i(\mathbf{X}_u)_i are returned). The (100 Ã—\timeslevel)% confidence interval for E[(yu)i]\text{E}[(y_u)_i] is (ğ—u)iğ›ƒÌ‚Â±z*(ğ—u)i(ğ—oâŠ¤ğšºÌ‚oâˆ’1ğ—o)âˆ’1(ğ—u)iâŠ¤(\mathbf{X}_u)_i \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}} \pm z^* \sqrt{(\mathbf{X}_u)_i (\mathbf{X}^\top_o \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_o^{-1} \mathbf{X}_o)^{-1} (\mathbf{X}_u)_i^\top} where (ğ—u)i(ğ—oâŠ¤ğšºÌ‚oâˆ’1ğ—o)âˆ’1(ğ—u)iâŠ¤\sqrt{(\mathbf{X}_u)_i (\mathbf{X}^\top_o \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_o^{-1} \mathbf{X}_o)^{-1} (\mathbf{X}_u)_i^\top} is the standard error of (yÌ‡u)i(\dot{y}_u)_i obtained from se.fit = TRUE, Î¦(z*)=1âˆ’Î±/2\Phi(z^*) = 1 - \alpha / 2, Î¦(â‹…)\Phi(\cdot) is the standard normal (Gaussian) cumulative distribution function, Î±=1âˆ’\alpha = 1 -level, and level is an argument to predict(). The default for level is 0.95, which corresponds to a z*z^* of approximately 1.96.

spautor() extra steps

For spatial autoregressive models, an extra step is required to obtain ğšºÌ‚oâˆ’1\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1}_o, ğšºÌ‚u\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_u, and ğšºÌ‚uo\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{uo} as they depend on one another through the neighborhood structure of ğ²o\mathbf{y}_o and ğ²u\mathbf{y}_u. Recall that for autoregressive models, it is ğšºâˆ’1\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1} that is straightforward to obtain, not ğšº\boldsymbol{\Sigma}.

Let ğšºâˆ’1\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1} be the inverse covariance matrix of the observed and unobserved data, ğ²o\mathbf{y}_o and ğ²u\mathbf{y}_u. One approach to obtain ğšºo\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_o and ğšºuo\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{uo} is to directly invert ğšºâˆ’1\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1} and then subset ğšº\boldsymbol{\Sigma} appropriately. This inversion can be prohibitive when no+nun_o + n_u is large. A faster way to obtain ğšºo\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_o and ğšºuo\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{uo} exists. Represent ğšºâˆ’1\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1} blockwise as ğšºâˆ’1=[ğšºÌƒoğšºÌƒuoâŠ¤ğšºÌƒuoğšºÌƒu],\begin{equation*}\label{eq:auto_hw} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{o} & \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{\top}_{uo} \\ \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{uo} & \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{u} \end{bmatrix}, \end{equation*} where the dimensions of the blocks match the relevant dimensions of ğšº\boldsymbol{\Sigma}. All of the terms required for prediction can be obtained from this block representation. Wolf (1978) shows that ğšºoâˆ’1=ğšºÌƒoâˆ’ğšºÌƒuoâŠ¤(ğšºÌƒu)âˆ’1ğšºÌƒuoğšºu=(ğšºÌƒuâˆ’ğšºÌƒuo(ğšºÌƒo)âˆ’1ğšºÌƒuoâŠ¤)âˆ’1ğšºuo=âˆ’ğšºuğšºÌƒuoğšºÌƒoâˆ’1\begin{equation*}\label{eq:hw_forms} \begin{split} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1}_o & = \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{o} - \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{ \top}_{uo} (\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{u})^{-1} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{uo} \\ \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_u & = (\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{u} - \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{uo} (\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{o})^{-1} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^\top_{uo})^{-1} \\ \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{uo} & = - \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_u \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{uo} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1}_{o} \end{split} \end{equation*} Evaluating these expressions at ğ›‰Ì‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}} yields ğšºÌ‚oâˆ’1\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1}_o, and ğšºÌ‚u\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_u, and ğšºÌ‚uo\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{uo}.

A similar result exists for the log determinant of ğšºo\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_o, which is not required for prediction but is required for restricted maximum likelihood and maximum likelihood estimation.

Big Data

When the number of observations in the fitted model (observed data) are large or there are many locations to predict or both, it is often necessary to implement computationally efficient big data approximations. Big data approximations are implemented in spmodel using the local argument to predict(). When the local method is "all", all of the fitted model data are used to make predictions. In this context, computational efficiency is only gained by parallelizing each prediction. The only available local method for spautor() fitted models is "all". This is because the neighborhood structure of spautor() fitted models does not permit the subsetting used by the "covariance" and "distance" methods that we discuss next.

When the local method is "covariance", ğšºÌ‚uo\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{uo} is computed between the observation being predicted (ğ²u\mathbf{y}_u) and the rest of the observed data. This vector is then ordered and a number of observations (specified via the size argument) having the highest covariance with ğ²u\mathbf{y}_u are subset, yielding ğšºÌŒuo\check{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{uo}, which has dimension 1Ã—size1 \times size. Then similarly ğšºÌ‚o\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_o, ğ²o\mathbf{y}_o, and ğ—u\mathbf{X}_u are also subset by these size observations, yielding ğšºÌŒo\check{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{o}, ğ²ÌŒo\check{\mathbf{y}}_o, and ğ—ÌŒu\check{\mathbf{X}}_u, respectively. The previous prediction equations can be evaluated at ğšºÌŒuo\check{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{uo}, ğšºÌŒo\check{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{o}, ğ²ÌŒo\check{\mathbf{y}}_o, and ğ—ÌŒu\check{\mathbf{X}}_u (except for the quantity (ğ—oâŠ¤ğšºÌ‚oâˆ’1ğ—o)âˆ’1(\mathbf{X}_o^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_o^{-1} \mathbf{X}_o)^{-1}, which is evaluated using all the observed data) to yield predictions and standard errors. When the local method is "distance", a similar approach is used except a number of observations (specified via the size argument) closest (in terms of Euclidean distance) to ğ²u\mathbf{y}_u are subset instead. When random effects are not used, partition factors are not used, and the spatial covariance function is monotone decreasing, "covariance" and "distance" are equivalent. This approach of subsetting the observed data by the set of locations closest in covariance or proximity to ğ²u\mathbf{y}_u is known as the local neighborhood approach. As long as size is relatively small (the default is 100), the local neighborhood approach is very computationally efficient, mainly because ğšºÌŒoâˆ’1\check{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}_{o}^{-1} is easy to compute. Additional computational efficiency is gained by parallelizing each prediction.

splmRF() and spautorRF()

Random forest spatial residual model predictions are obtained by combining random forest predictions and spatial linear model predictions (i.e., Kriging) of the random forest residuals. Formally, the random forest spatial residual model predictions of ğ²u\mathbf{y}_u are given by ğ²Ì‡u=ğ²Ì‡u,rf+ğÌ‡u,slm,\begin{equation*} \mathbf{\dot{y}}_u = \mathbf{\dot{y}}_{u, rf} + \mathbf{\dot{e}}_{u, slm}, \end{equation*} where ğ²Ì‡u,rf\mathbf{\dot{y}}_{u, rf} are the random forest predictions for ğ²u\mathbf{y}_u and ğÌ‡u,slm\mathbf{\dot{e}}_{u, slm} are the spatial linear model predictions of the random forest residuals for ğ²u\mathbf{y}_u. This process of obtaining predictions is sometimes analogously called random forest regression Kriging (Fox, Ver Hoef, and Olsen 2020).

Uncertainty quantification in a random forest context has been studied (Meinshausen and Ridgeway 2006) but is not currently available in spmodel. Big data are accommodated by supplying the local argument to predict().

pseudoR2()

The pseudo R-squared is a generalization of the classical R-squared from non-spatial linear models. Like the classical R-squared, the pseudo R-squared measures the proportion of variability in the response explained by the fixed effects in the fitted model. Unlike the classical R-squared, the pseudo R-squared can be applied to models whose errors do not satisfy the iid and constant variance assumption. The pseudo R-squared is given by PR2=1âˆ’ğ’Ÿ(ğš¯Ì‚)ğ’Ÿ(ğš¯Ì‚0).\begin{equation*} PR2 = 1 - \frac{\mathcal{D}(\boldsymbol{\hat{\Theta}})}{\mathcal{D}(\boldsymbol{\hat{\Theta}}_0)}. \end{equation*} For normal (Gaussian) random errors, the pseudo R-squared is PR2=1âˆ’(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌ‚)âŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌ‚)(ğ²âˆ’Î¼Ì‚)âŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1(ğ²âˆ’Î¼Ì‚),\begin{equation*} PR2 = 1 - \frac{(\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}})^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1}(\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}})}{(\mathbf{y} - \hat{\mu})^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1}(\mathbf{y} - \hat{\mu})}, \end{equation*} where Î¼Ì‚=(ğŸâŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1ğŸ)âˆ’1ğŸâŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1ğ²\hat{\mu} = (\boldsymbol{1}^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1} \boldsymbol{1})^{-1} \boldsymbol{1}^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1} \mathbf{y}. For the non-spatial model, the pseudo R-squared reduces to the classical R-squared, as PR2=1âˆ’(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌ‚)âŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌ‚)(ğ²âˆ’Î¼Ì‚)âŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1(ğ²âˆ’Î¼Ì‚)=1âˆ’(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌ‚)âŠ¤(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌ‚)(ğ²âˆ’Î¼Ì‚)âŠ¤(ğ²âˆ’Î¼Ì‚)=1âˆ’SSESST=R2,\begin{equation*} PR2 = 1 - \frac{(\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}})^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1}(\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}})}{(\mathbf{y} - \hat{\mu})^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1}(\mathbf{y} - \hat{\mu})} = 1 - \frac{(\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}})^\top (\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}})}{(\mathbf{y} - \hat{\mu})^\top (\mathbf{y} - \hat{\mu})} = 1 - \frac{\text{SSE}}{\text{SST}} = R2, \end{equation*} where SSE denotes the error sum of squares and SST denotes the total sum of squares. The result follows because for a non-spatial model, ğšº\boldsymbol{\Sigma} is proportional to the identity matrix.

The adjusted pseudo r-squared adjusts for additional explanatory variables and is given by PR2adj=1âˆ’(1âˆ’PR2)nâˆ’1nâˆ’p.\begin{equation*} PR2adj = 1 - (1 - PR2)\frac{n - 1}{n - p}. \end{equation*} If the fitted model does not have an intercept, the nâˆ’1n - 1 term is instead nn.

residuals()

Terminology regarding residual names is often conflicting and confusing. Because of this, we explicitly define the residual options we use in spmodel. These definitions may be different from others you have seen in the literature.

When type = "response", response residuals are returned: ğr=ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌ‚.\begin{equation*} \mathbf{e}_{r} = \mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}. \end{equation*}

When type = "pearson", Pearson residuals are returned: ğp=ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1/2ğr,\begin{equation*} \mathbf{e}_{p} = \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1/2}\mathbf{e}_{r}, \end{equation*} If the errors are normal (Gaussian), the Pearson residuals should be approximately normally distributed with mean zero and variance one. The result follows when ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1/2â‰ˆğšºâˆ’1/2\hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1/2} \approx \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2} because E(ğšºâˆ’1/2ğr)=ğšºâˆ’1/2E(ğr)=ğšºâˆ’1/2ğŸ=ğŸ\begin{equation*} \text{E}(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2} \mathbf{e}_{r}) = \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2} \text{E}(\mathbf{e}_{r}) = \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2} \boldsymbol{0} = \boldsymbol{0} \end{equation*} and Cov(ğšºâˆ’1/2ğr)=ğšºâˆ’1/2Cov(ğr)ğšºâˆ’1/2â‰ˆğšºâˆ’1/2ğšºğšºâˆ’1/2=(ğšºâˆ’1/2ğšº1/2)(ğšº1/2ğšºâˆ’1/2)=ğˆ\begin{equation*} \begin{split} \text{Cov}(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2} \mathbf{e}_{r}) & = \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2} \text{Cov}(\mathbf{e}_{r}) \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2} \\ & \approx \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2} \boldsymbol{\Sigma} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2} \\ & = (\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1/2})(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{1/2} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2}) \\ & = \mathbf{I} \end{split} \end{equation*}

When type = "standardized", standardized residuals are returned: ğs=ğpâŠ™11âˆ’diag(ğ‡*),\begin{equation*} \mathbf{e}_{s} = \mathbf{e}_{p} \odot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - diag(\mathbf{H}^*)}}, \end{equation*} where diag(ğ‡*)diag(\mathbf{H}^*) is the diagonal of the spatial hat matrix, ğ‡sâ‰¡ğ—*(ğ—*âŠ¤ğ—*)âˆ’1ğ—*âŠ¤\mathbf{H}_s \equiv \mathbf{X}^* (\mathbf{X}^{* \top} \mathbf{X}^*)^{-1} \mathbf{X}^{* \top}, and âŠ™\odot denotes the Hadmard (element-wise) product. This residual transformation â€œstandardizesâ€ the Pearson residuals. As such, the standardized residuals should also have mean zero and variance Cov(ğs)=Cov((ğˆâˆ’ğ‡*)ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1/2ğ²)â‰ˆCov((ğˆâˆ’ğ‡*)ğšºâˆ’1/2ğ²)=(ğˆâˆ’ğ‡*)ğšºâˆ’1/2Cov(ğ²)ğšºâˆ’1/2(ğˆâˆ’ğ‡*)âŠ¤=(ğˆâˆ’ğ‡*)ğšºâˆ’1/2ğšºğšºâˆ’1/2(ğˆâˆ’ğ‡*)âŠ¤=(ğˆâˆ’ğ‡*)ğˆ(ğˆâˆ’ğ‡*)âŠ¤=(ğˆâˆ’ğ‡*),\begin{equation*} \begin{split} \text{Cov}(\mathbf{e}_{s}) & = \text{Cov}((\mathbf{I} - \mathbf{H}^*) \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1/2}\mathbf{y}) \\ & \approx \text{Cov}((\mathbf{I} - \mathbf{H}^*) \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2}\mathbf{y}) \\ & = (\mathbf{I} - \mathbf{H}^*) \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2} \text{Cov}(\mathbf{y}) \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2}(\mathbf{I} - \mathbf{H}^*)^\top \\ & = (\mathbf{I} - \mathbf{H}^*) \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2} \boldsymbol{\Sigma} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1/2}(\mathbf{I} - \mathbf{H}^*)^\top \\ & = (\mathbf{I} - \mathbf{H}^*) \mathbf{I} (\mathbf{I} - \mathbf{H}^*)^\top \\ & = (\mathbf{I} - \mathbf{H}^*), \end{split} \end{equation*} because (ğˆâˆ’ğ‡*)(\mathbf{I} - \mathbf{H}^*) is symmetric and idempotent. Note that the average value of diag(ğ‡*)diag(\mathbf{H}^*) is p/np / n, so (ğˆâˆ’ğ‡*)â‰ˆğˆ(\mathbf{I} - \mathbf{H}^*) \approx \mathbf{I} for large sample sizes.

spautor() and splm()

Next we discuss technical details for the spautor() and splm() functions. Many of the details for the two functions are the same, though occasional differences are noted in the following subsection headers. Specifically, spautor() and splm() are for different data types and use different covariance functions. spautor() is for spatial linear models with areal data (i.e., spatial autoregressive models) and splm() is for spatial linear models with point-referenced data (i.e., geostatistical models). There are also a few features splm() has that spautor() does not: semivariogram-based estimation, random effects, anisotropy, and big data approximations.

spautor() Spatial Covariance Functions

For areal data, the covariance matrix depends on the specification of a neighborhood structure among the observations. Observations with at least one neighbor (not including itself) are called â€œconnectedâ€ observations. Observations with no neighbors are called â€œunconnectedâ€ observations. The autoregressive spatial covariance matrix can be defined as ğšº=[Ïƒde2ğ‘ğŸğŸÏƒÎ¾2ğˆ]+Ïƒie2ğˆ,\begin{equation*} \boldsymbol{\Sigma} = \begin{bmatrix} \sigma^2_{de} \mathbf{R} & \mathbf{0} \\ \mathbf{0} & \sigma^2_{\xi} \mathbf{I} \end{bmatrix} + \sigma^2_{ie} \mathbf{I}, \end{equation*} where Ïƒde2\sigma^2_{de}(â‰¥0)(\geq 0) is the spatially dependent (correlated) variance for the connected observations, ğ‘\mathbf{R} is a matrix that describes the spatial dependence for the connected observations, ÏƒÎ¾2\sigma^2_{\xi}(â‰¥0)(\geq 0) is the independent (not correlated) variance for the unconnected observations, and Ïƒie2\sigma^2_{ie}(â‰¥0)(\geq 0) is the independent (not correlated) variance for all observations. As seen, the connected and unconnected observations are allowed different variances. The total variance for connected observations is then Ïƒde2+Ïƒie2\sigma^2_{de} + \sigma^2_{ie} and the total variance for unconnected observations is ÏƒÎ¾2+Ïƒie2\sigma^2_{\xi} + \sigma^2_{ie}. spmodel accommodates two spatial covariances: conditional autoregressive (CAR) and simultaneous autoregressive (SAR), both of which have their ğ‘\mathbf{R} forms provided in the following table.

The forms of R for each spatial covariance type available in spautor()
Spatial covariance type ğ‘\mathbf{R} functional form
"ğšŒğšŠğš›"\texttt{"car"} (ğˆâˆ’Ï•ğ–)âˆ’1ğŒ(\mathbf{I} - \phi\mathbf{W})^{-1}\mathbf{M}
"ğšœğšŠğš›"\texttt{"sar"} [(ğˆâˆ’Ï•ğ–)(ğˆâˆ’Ï•ğ–)âŠ¤]âˆ’1[(\mathbf{I} - \phi\mathbf{W})(\mathbf{I} - \phi\mathbf{W})^\top]^{-1}

For both CAR and SAR covariance functions, ğ‘\mathbf{R} depends on similar quantities: ğˆ\mathbf{I}, an identity matrix; Ï•\phi, a range parameter, and ğ–\mathbf{W}, a matrix that defines the neighborhood structure. Often ğ–\mathbf{W} is symmetric but it need not be. Valid values for Ï•\phi are in (1/Î»min,1/Î»max)(1 / \lambda_{min}, 1 / \lambda_{max}), where Î»min\lambda_{min} is the minimum eigenvalue of ğ–\mathbf{W} and Î»max\lambda_{max} is the maximum eigenvalue of ğ–\mathbf{W}(Ver Hoef et al. 2018). For SAR covariance functions, Î»min\lambda_{min} must be negative and Î»max\lambda_{max} must be positive. For CAR covariances functions, a matrix ğŒ\mathbf{M} matrix must be provided that satisfies the CAR symmetry condition, which enforces the symmetry of the covariance matrix. The CAR symmetry condition states ğ–ijğŒii=ğ–jiğŒjj\begin{equation*} \frac{\mathbf{W}_{ij}}{\mathbf{M}_{ii}} = \frac{\mathbf{W}_{ji}}{\mathbf{M}_{jj}} \end{equation*} for all ii and jj, where ii and jj index rows or columns. When ğ–\mathbf{W} is symmetric, ğŒ\mathbf{M} is often taken to be the identity matrix.

The default in spmodel is to row-standardize ğ–\mathbf{W} by dividing each element by its respective row sum, which decreases variance. If row-standardization is not used for a CAR model, the default in spmodel for ğŒ\mathbf{M} is the identity matrix.

splm() Spatial Covariance Functions

For point-referenced data, the spatial covariance is given by Ïƒde2ğ‘+Ïƒie2ğˆ,\begin{equation*} \sigma^2_{de}\mathbf{R} + \sigma^2_{ie} \mathbf{I}, \end{equation*} where Ïƒde2\sigma^2_{de}(â‰¥0)(\geq 0) is the spatially dependent (correlated) variance, ğ‘\mathbf{R} is a spatial correlation matrix, Ïƒie2\sigma^2_{ie}(â‰¥0)(\geq 0) is the spatially independent (not correlated) variance, and ğˆ\mathbf{I} is an identity matrix. The ğ‘\mathbf{R} matrix always depends on a range parameter, Ï•\phi(>0)(> 0), that controls the behavior of the covariance function with distance. For some covariance functions, the ğ‘\mathbf{R} matrix depends on an additional parameter that we call the â€œextraâ€ parameter. The following table shows the parametric form for all ğ‘\mathbf{R} matrices available in splm(). The range parameter is denoted as Ï•\phi, the distance is denoted as hh, the distance divided by the range parameter (h/Ï•h / \phi) is denoted as Î·\eta, â„{â‹…}\mathcal{I}\{\cdot\} is an indicator function equal to one when the argument occurs and zero otherwise, and the extra parameter is denoted as Î¾\xi (when relevant).

The forms of R for each spatial covariance type available in splm(). All spatial covariance functions are valid in two dimensions except the triangular and cosine functions, which are only valid in one dimension.

"ğšğš¡ğš™ğš˜ğš—ğšğš—ğšğš’ğšŠğš•"\texttt{"exponential"} eâˆ’Î·e^{-\eta}

Model-fitting

Likelihood-based Estimation (estmethod = "reml" or estmethod = "ml")

Minus twice a profiled (by ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta}) Gaussian log-likelihood is given by âˆ’2â„“p(ğ›‰)=ln|ğšº|+(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌƒ)âŠ¤ğšºâˆ’1(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌƒ)+nln2Ï€,\begin{equation}\label{eq:ml-lik} -2\ell_p(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = \ln{|\boldsymbol{\Sigma}|} + (\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}})^\top \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1} (\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}) + n \ln{2\pi}, \end{equation} where ğ›ƒÌƒ=(ğ—âŠ¤ğšºâˆ’1ğ—)âˆ’1ğ—âŠ¤ğšºâˆ’1ğ²\tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}} = (\mathbf{X}^\top \mathbf{\Sigma}^{-1} \mathbf{X})^{-1} \mathbf{X}^\top \mathbf{\Sigma}^{-1} \mathbf{y}. Minimizing this equation yields ğ›‰Ì‚ml\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}_{ml}, the maximum likelihood estimates for ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta}. Then a closed form solution exists for ğ›ƒÌ‚ml\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}_{ml}, the maximum likelihood estimates for ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta}: ğ›ƒÌ‚ml=ğ›ƒÌƒml\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}_{ml} = \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{ml}, where ğ›ƒÌƒml\tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{ml} is ğ›ƒÌƒ\tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}} evaluated at ğ›‰Ì‚ml\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}_{ml}. To reduce bias in that variances of ğ›ƒÌ‚ml\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}_{ml} that can occur due to the simultaneous estimation of ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta} and ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta}, restricted maximum likelihood estimation (REML) (Patterson and Thompson 1971; Harville 1977; Wolfinger, Tobias, and Sall 1994) has been shown to be better than maximum likelihood estimation. Integrating ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta} out of a Gaussian likelihood yields the restricted Gaussian likelihood. Minus twice a restricted Gaussian log-likelihood is given by âˆ’2â„“R(ğ›‰)=âˆ’2â„“p(ğ›‰)+ln|ğ—âŠ¤ğšºâˆ’1ğ—|âˆ’pln2Ï€,\begin{equation}\label{eq:reml-lik} -2\ell_R(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = -2\ell_p(\boldsymbol{\theta}) + \ln{|\mathbf{X}^\top \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1} \mathbf{X}|} - p \ln{2\pi} , \end{equation} where pp equals the dimension of ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta}. Minimizing this equation yields ğ›‰Ì‚reml\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}_{reml}, the restricted maximum likelihood estimates for ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta}. Then a closed for solution exists for ğ›ƒÌ‚reml\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}_{reml}, the restricted maximum likelihood estimates for ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta}: ğ›ƒÌ‚reml=ğ›ƒÌƒreml\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}_{reml} = \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{reml}, where ğ›ƒÌƒreml\tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{reml} is ğ›ƒÌƒ\tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}} evaluated at ğ›‰Ì‚reml\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}_{reml}.

The covariance matrix can often be written as ğšº=Ïƒ2ğšº*\boldsymbol{\Sigma} = \sigma^2 \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^*, where Ïƒ2\sigma^2 is the overall variance and ğšº*\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^* is a covariance matrix that depends on parameter vector ğ›‰*\boldsymbol{\theta}^* with one less dimension than ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta}. Then the overall variance, Ïƒ2\sigma^2, can be profiled out of the previous likelihood equation. This reduces the number of parameters requiring optimization by one, which can dramatically reduce estimation time. Further profiling out Ïƒ2\sigma^2 yields âˆ’2â„“p*(ğ›‰*)=ln|ğšº*|+nln[(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌƒ)âŠ¤ğšº*âˆ’1(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌƒ)]+n+nln2Ï€/n.\begin{equation*}\label{eq:ml-plik} -2\ell_p^*(\boldsymbol{\theta}^*) = \ln{|\boldsymbol{\Sigma^*}|} + n\ln[(\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}})^\top \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{* -1} (\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}})] + n + n\ln{2\pi / n}. \end{equation*} After finding ğ›‰Ì‚ml*\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^*_{ml}, a closed form solution for ÏƒÌ‚ml2\hat{\sigma}^2_{ml} exists: ÏƒÌ‚ml2=[(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌƒ)âŠ¤ğšº*âˆ’1(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌƒ)]/n\hat{\sigma}^2_{ml} = [(\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\tilde{\beta}})^\top \mathbf{\Sigma}^{* -1} (\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}})] / n. Then ğ›‰Ì‚ml*\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}^*_{ml} is combined with ÏƒÌ‚ml2\hat{\sigma}^2_{ml} to yield ğ›‰Ì‚ml\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}_{ml} and subsequently ğ›ƒÌ‚ml\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}_{ml}. A similar result holds for restricted maximum likelihood estimation. Further profiling out Ïƒ2\sigma^2 yields âˆ’2â„“R*(ğš¯)=ln|ğšº*|+(nâˆ’p)ln[(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌƒ)âŠ¤ğšº*âˆ’1(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌƒ)]+ln|ğ—âŠ¤ğšº*âˆ’1ğ—|+(nâˆ’p)+(nâˆ’p)ln2Ï€/(nâˆ’p).\begin{equation*}\label{eq:reml-plik} -2\ell_R^*(\boldsymbol{\Theta}) = \ln{|\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^*|} + (n - p)\ln[(\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}})^\top \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{* -1} (\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}})] + \ln{|\mathbf{X}^\top \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{* -1} \mathbf{X}|} + (n - p) + (n - p)\ln2\pi / (n - p). \end{equation*} After finding ğ›‰Ì‚reml*\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^*_{reml}, a closed form solution for ÏƒÌ‚reml2\hat{\sigma}^2_{reml} exists: ÏƒÌ‚reml2=[(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌƒ)âŠ¤ğšº*âˆ’1(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒÌƒ)]/(nâˆ’p)\hat{\sigma}^2_{reml} = [(\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\tilde{\beta}})^\top \mathbf{\Sigma}^{* -1} (\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}})] / (n - p). Then ğ›‰Ì‚reml*\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}^*_{reml} is combined with ÏƒÌ‚reml2\hat{\sigma}^2_{reml} to yield ğ›‰Ì‚reml\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}_{reml} and subsequently ğ›ƒÌ‚reml\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}_{reml}. For more on profiling Gaussian likelihoods, see Wolfinger, Tobias, and Sall (1994).

Both maximum likelihood and restricted maximum likelihood estimation rely on the nÃ—nn \times n covariance matrix inverse. Inverting an nÃ—nn \times n matrix is an enormous computational demand that scales cubically with the sample size. For this reason, maximum likelihood and restricted maximum likelihood estimation have historically been infeasible to implement in their standard form with data larger than a few thousand observations. This motivates the use for big data approaches.

Semivariogram-based Estimation (splm() only)

An alternative approach to likelihood-based estimation is semivariogram-based estimation. The semivariogram of a constant-mean process ğ²\mathbf{y} is the expectation of half of the squared difference between two observations hh distance apart. More formally, the semivariogram is denoted Î³(h)\gamma(h) and defined as Î³(h)=E[(yiâˆ’yj)2]/2,\begin{equation*}\label{eq:sv} \gamma(h) = \text{E}[(y_i - y_j)^2] / 2 , \end{equation*} where hh is the Euclidean distance between the locations of yiy_i and yjy_j. When the process ğ²\mathbf{y} is second-order stationary, the semivariogram and covariance function are intimately connected: Î³(h)=Ïƒ2âˆ’Cov(h)\gamma(h) = \sigma^2 - \text{Cov}(h), where Ïƒ2\sigma^2 is the overall variance and Cov(h)\text{Cov}(h) is the covariance function evaluated at hh. As such, the semivariogram and covariance function rely on the same parameter vector ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta}. Both of the semivariogram approaches described next are more computationally efficient than restricted maximum likelihood and maximum likelihood estimation because the major computational burden of the semivariogram approaches (calculations based on squared differences among pairs) scales quadratically with the sample size (i.e., not the cubed sample size like the likelihood-based approaches).

Weighted Least Squares (estmethod = "sv-wls")

The empirical semivariogram is a moment-based estimate of the semivariogram denoted by Î³Ì‚(h)\hat{\gamma}(h). It is defined as Î³Ì‚(h)=12|N(h)|âˆ‘N(h)(yiâˆ’yj)2,\begin{equation*} \hat{\gamma}(h) = \frac{1}{2|N(h)|} \sum_{N(h)} (y_i - y_j)^2, \end{equation*} where N(h)N(h) is the set of observations in ğ²\mathbf{y} that are hh distance units apart (distance classes) and |N(h)||N(h)| is the cardinality of N(h)N(h)(Cressie 1993). One criticism of the empirical semivariogram is that distance bins and cutoffs tend to be arbitrarily chosen (i.e., not chosen according to some statistical criteria).

Cressie (1985) proposed estimating ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta} by minimizing an objective function that involves Î³(h)\gamma(h) and Î³Ì‚(h)\hat{\gamma}(h) and is based on a weighted least squares criterion. This criterion is defined as âˆ‘iwi[Î³Ì‚(h)iâˆ’Î³(h)i]2,\begin{equation}\label{eq:svwls} \sum_i w_i [\hat{\gamma}(h)_i - \gamma(h)_i]^2, \end{equation} where wiw_i, Î³Ì‚(h)i\hat{\gamma}(h)_i, and Î³(h)i\gamma(h)_i are the weights, empirical semivariogram, and semivariogram for the iith distance class, respectively. Minimizing this loss function yields ğ›‰Ì‚wls\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}_{wls}, the semivariogram weighted least squares estimate of ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta}. After estimating ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta}, ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta} estimates are constructed using (empirical) generalized least squares: ğ›ƒÌ‚wls=(ğ—âŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1ğ—)âˆ’1ğ—âŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1ğ²\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}_{wls} = (\mathbf{X}^\top \hat{\mathbf{\Sigma}}^{-1} \mathbf{X})^{-1} \mathbf{X}^\top \hat{\mathbf{\Sigma}}^{-1} \mathbf{y}.

Cressie (1985) recommends setting wi=|N(h)|/Î³(h)i2w_i = |N(h)| / \gamma(h)_i^2, which gives more weight to distance classes with more observations (|N(h)||N(h)|) and shorter distances (1/Î³(h)i21 / \gamma(h)_i^2). The default in spmodel is to use these wiw_i, known as Cressie weights, though several other options for wiw_i exist and are available via the weights argument. The following table contains all wiw_i available via the weights argument.

Table of values for the weights argument in splm() when estmethod = â€œsv-wlsâ€.
wiw_i Name wiw_i Form ğš ğšğš’ğšğš‘ğš =\texttt{weight =}

Cressie (Denominator) Root |N(h)|/Î³(h)i|N(h)| / \gamma(h)_i "ğšŒğš›ğšğšœğšœğš’ğš-ğšğš›"\texttt{"cressie-dr"}

Ordinary Least Squares 1 "ğš˜ğš•ğšœ"\texttt{"ols"}

The number of N(h)N(h) classes and the maximum distance for hh are specified by passing the bins and cutoff arguments to splm() (these arguments are passed via ... to esv()). The default value for bins is 15 and the default value for cutoff is half the maximum distance of the spatial domainâ€™s bounding box.

Recall that the semivariogram is defined for a constant-mean process. Generally, ğ²\mathbf{y} does not necessarily have a constant mean so the empirical semivariogram and ğ›‰Ì‚wls\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}_{wls} are typically constructed using the residuals from an ordinary least squares regression of ğ²\mathbf{y} on ğ—\mathbf{X}. These ordinary least squares residuals are assumed to have mean zero.

Composite Likelihood (estmethod = "sv-cl")

Composite likelihood approaches involve constructing likelihoods based on conditional or marginal events for which likelihoods are available and then adding together these individual components. Composite likelihoods are attractive because they behave very similar to likelihoods but are easier to handle, both from a theoretical and from a computational perspective. Curriero and Lele (1999) derive a particular composite likelihood for estimating semivariogram parameters. The negative log of this composite likelihood, denoted CL(h)\text{CL}(h), is given by CL(h)=âˆ‘i=1nâˆ’1âˆ‘j>i((yiâˆ’yj)22Î³(h)+ln(Î³(h)))\begin{equation}\label{eq:svcl} \text{CL}(h) = \sum_{i = 1}^{n - 1} \sum_{j > i} \left( \frac{(y_i - y_j)^2}{2\gamma(h)} + \ln(\gamma(h)) \right) \end{equation} where Î³(h)\gamma(h) is the semivariogram. Minimizing this loss function yields ğ›‰Ì‚cl\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}_{cl}, the semivariogram composite likelihood estimates of ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta}. After estimating ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta}, ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol{\beta} estimates are constructed using (empirical) generalized least squares: ğ›ƒÌ‚cl=(ğ—âŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1ğ—)âˆ’1ğ—âŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1ğ²\boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}}_{cl} = (\mathbf{X}^\top \hat{\mathbf{\Sigma}}^{-1} \mathbf{X})^{-1} \mathbf{X}^\top \hat{\mathbf{\Sigma}}^{-1} \mathbf{y}.

An advantage of the composite likelihood approach to semivariogram estimation is that it does not require arbitrarily specifying empirical semivariogram bins and cutoffs. It does tend to be more computationally demanding than weighted least squares, however. The composite likelihood is constructed from (n2)\binom{n}{2} pairs for a sample size nn, whereas the weighted least squares approach only requires calculating (|N(h)|2)\binom{|N(h)|}{2} pairs for each distance bin N(h)N(h). As with the weighted least squares approach, the composite likelihood approach requires a constant-mean process, so typically the residuals from an ordinary least squares regression of ğ²\mathbf{y} on ğ—\mathbf{X} are used to estimate ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta}.

Optimization

Parameter estimation is performed using stats::optim(). The default estimation method is Nelder-Mead (Nelder and Mead 1965) and the stopping criterion is a relative convergence tolerance (reltol) of .0001. If only one parameter requires estimation (on the profiled scale if relevant), the Brent algorithm is instead used (Brent 1971). Arguments to optim() are passed via ... to splm() and spautor(). For example, the default estimation method and convergence criteria are overridden by passing method and control, respectively, to splm() and spautor(). If the lower and upper arguments to optim() are specified in splm() and spautor() to be passed to optim(), they are ignored, as optimization for all parameters is generally unconstrained. Initial values for optim() are found using the grid search described next.

Grid Search

spmodel uses a grid search to find suitable initial values for use in optimization. For spatial linear models without random effects, the spatially dependent variance (Ïƒde2\sigma^2_{de}) and spatially independent variance (Ïƒie2\sigma^2_{ie}) parameters are given â€œlowâ€, â€œmediumâ€, and â€œhighâ€ values. The sample variance of a non-spatial linear model is slightly inflated by a factor of 1.2 (non-spatial models can underestimate the variance when there is spatial dependence) and these â€œlowâ€, â€œmediumâ€, and â€œhighâ€ values correspond to 10%, 50%, and 90% of the inflated sample variance. Only combinations of Ïƒde2\sigma^2_{de} and Ïƒie2\sigma^2_{ie} whose proportions sum to 100% are considered. The range (Ï•\phi) and extra (Î¾\xi) parameters are given â€œlowâ€ and â€œhighâ€ values that are unique to each spatial covariance function. For example, when using an exponential covariance function, the â€œlowâ€ value of Ï•\phi is one-half the diagonal of the domainâ€™s bounding box divided by three. This particular value is chosen so that the effective range (the distance at which the covariance is approximately zero), which equals 3Ï•3\phi for the exponential covariance function, is is reached at one-half the diagonal of the domainâ€™s bounding box. Analogously, the â€œhighâ€ value of Ï•\phi is three-halves the diagonal of the domainâ€™s bounding box divided by three. The anisotropy rotation parameter (Î±\alpha) is given six values that correspond to 0, Ï€/6\pi/6, 2Ï€/62\pi/6, 4Ï€/64\pi/6, 5Ï€/65\pi/6, and Ï€\pi radians. The anisotropy scale parameter (SS) is given â€œlowâ€, â€œmediumâ€, and â€œhighâ€ values that correspond to scaling factors of 0.25, 0.75, and 1. Note that the anisotropy parameters are only used during grid searches for point-referenced data.

The crossing of all appropriate parameter values is considered. If initial values are used for a parameter, the initial value replaces all values of the parameter in this crossing. Duplicate crossings are then omitted. The parameter configuration that yields the smallest value of the objective function is then used as an initial value for optimization. Suppose the inflated sample variance is 10, the exponential covariance is used assuming isotropy, and the diagonal of the bounding box is 180 distance units. The parameter configurations evaluated are shown in the following table.

Grid search parameter configurations for an isotropic exponential spatial covariance with inflated sample variance equal to 10 and diagonal of the bounding box equal to 180 distance units.
Ïƒde2\sigma^2_{de} Ïƒie2\sigma^2_{ie} Ï•\phi Î±\alpha SS
9 1 15 0 1
1 9 15 0 1
5 5 15 0 1
9 1 45 0 1
1 9 45 0 1
5 5 15 0 1

For spatial linear models with random effects, the same approach is used to create a crossing of spatial covariance parameters. A separate approach is used to create a set of random effect variances. The random effect variances are similarly first grouped by proportions. The first combination is such that the first random effect variance is given 90% of variance, and the remaining 10% is spread out evenly among the remaining random effect variances. The second combination is such that the second random effect variance is given 90% of the variance, and the remaining 10% is spread out evenly among the remaining random effect variances. And so on and so forth. These combinations ascertain whether one random effect dominates variability. A final grouping is lastly considered: all 100% of variance is spread out evenly among all random effects.

When finding parameter values Ïƒde2\sigma^2_{de}, Ïƒie2\sigma^2_{ie}, and the random effect variances (Ïƒui2\sigma^2_{u_i} for the iith random effect), three scenarios are considered. In the first scenario, Ïƒde2\sigma^2_{de} and Ïƒie2\sigma^2_{ie} get 90% of the inflated sample variance and the random effect variances get 10%. In this scenario, only the random effect grouping where the variance is evenly spread out is considered. This is because the random effect variances are already contributing little to the overall variability, so performing additional objective function evaluations is unnecessary. In the second scenario, the random effects get 90% of the inflated sample variances and Ïƒde2\sigma^2_{de} and Ïƒie2\sigma^2_{ie} get 10%. Similarly in this scenario, only the Ïƒde2\sigma^2_{de} and Ïƒie2\sigma^2_{ie} grouping where the variance is evenly spread out is considered. Also in this scenario, only the lowest value for range and extra are used. In the third scenario, the 50% of the inflated sample variance is given to Ïƒde2\sigma^2_{de} and Ïƒie2\sigma^2_{ie} and 50% to the random effects. In this scenario, the only parameter combination considered is the case where variances are evenly spread out among Ïƒde2\sigma^2_{de}, Ïƒie2\sigma^2_{ie}, and the random effect variances. Together, there are parameter configurations where the spatial variability dominates (scenario 1), the random variability dominates (scenario 2), and where there is an even contribution from spatial and random variability. The parameter configuration that minimizes the objective function is then used as an initial value for optimization. Recall that random effects are only used with restricted maximum likelihood or maximum likelihood estimation, so the objective function is always a likelihood.

Suppose the inflated sample variance is 10, the exponential covariance is used assuming isotropy, the diagonal of the bounding box is 180 distance units, and there are two random effects. The parameter configurations evaluated are shown in the following table.

Grid search parameter configurations for an isotropic exponential spatial covariance with two random effects, inflated sample variance equal to 10, and diagonal of the bounding box equal to 180 distance units.
Ïƒde2\sigma^2_{de} Ïƒie2\sigma^2_{ie} Ï•\phi Î±\alpha SS Ïƒu12\sigma^2_{u1} Ïƒu22\sigma^2_{u2}
8.1 0.9 15 0 1 0.5 0.5
0.9 8.1 15 0 1 0.5 0.5
4.5 4.5 15 0 1 0.5 0.5
8.1 0.9 45 0 1 0.5 0.5
0.9 8.1 45 0 1 0.5 0.5
4.5 4.5 45 0 1 0.5 0.5
0.5 0.5 15 0 1 8.1 0.9
0.5 0.5 15 0 1 0.9 8.1
0.5 0.5 15 0 1 4.5 4.5
2.5 2.5 15 0 1 2.5 2.5
2.5 2.5 45 0 1 2.5 2.5

This grid search approach balances a thorough exploration of the parameter space with computational efficiency, as each objective function evaluation can be computationally expensive.

Hypothesis Testing

The hypothesis tests for ğ›ƒÌ‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}} returned by summary() or tidy() of an splm or spautor object are asymptotic z-tests based on the normal (Gaussian) distribution (Wald tests). The null hypothesis for the test associated with each Î²Ì‚i\hat{\beta}_i is that Î²i=0\beta_i = 0. Then the test statistic is given by zÌƒ=Î²Ì‚iSE(Î²Ì‚i),\begin{equation*} \tilde{z} = \frac{\hat{\beta}_i}{\text{SE}(\hat{\beta}_i)}, \end{equation*} where SE(Î²Ì‚i)\text{SE}(\hat{\beta}_i) is the standard error of Î²Ì‚i\hat{\beta}_i, which equals the square root of the iith diagonal element of (ğ—âŠ¤ğšºÌ‚âˆ’1ğ—)âˆ’1(\mathbf{X}^\top \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{-1} \mathbf{X})^{-1}. The p-value is given by 2*(1âˆ’Î¦(|zÌƒ|))2 * (1 - \Phi(|\tilde{z}|)), which corresponds to an equal-tailed, two-sided hypothesis test of level Î±\alpha where Î¦(â‹…)\Phi(\cdot) denotes the standard normal (Gaussian) cumulative distribution function and |â‹…||\cdot| denotes the absolute value.

Random Effects (splm() only and "reml" or "ml" estmethod only)

The random effects contribute directly to the covariance through their design matrices. Let ğ®\mathbf{u} be a mean-zero random effect column vector of length nun_u, where nun_u is the number of levels of the random effect, with design matrix ğ™u\mathbf{Z}_u. Then Cov(ğ™uğ®)=ğ™uCov(ğ®)ğ™uâŠ¤\text{Cov}(\mathbf{Z}_u\mathbf{u}) = \mathbf{Z}_u \text{Cov}(\mathbf{u})\mathbf{Z}_u^\top. Because each element of ğ®\mathbf{u} is independent of one another, this reduces to Cov(ğ™uğ®)=Ïƒu2ğ™uğ™uâŠ¤\text{Cov}(\mathbf{Z}_u\mathbf{u}) = \sigma^2_u \mathbf{Z}_u \mathbf{Z}_u^\top, where Ïƒu2\sigma^2_u is the variance parameter corresponding to the random effect (i.e., the random effect variance parameter).

The ğ™\mathbf{Z} matrices index the levels of the random effect. ğ™\mathbf{Z} has dimension nÃ—nun \times n_u, where nn is the sample size. Each row of ğ™\mathbf{Z} corresponds to an observation and each column to a level of the random effect. For example, suppose we have n=4n = 4 observations, so ğ²={y1,y2,y3,y4}\mathbf{y} = \{y_1, y_2, y_3, y_4\}. Also suppose that the random effect ğ®\mathbf{u} has two levels and that y1y_1 and y4y_4 are in the first level and y2y_2 and y3y_3 are in the second level. For random intercepts, each element of ğ™\mathbf{Z} is one if the observation is in the appropriate level of the random effect and zero otherwise. So it follows that ğ™ğ®=[10010110][u1u2],\begin{equation*} \mathbf{Z}\mathbf{u} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} u_1 \\ u_2 \end{bmatrix}, \end{equation*} where u1u_1 and u2u_2 are the random intercepts for the first and second levels of ğ®\mathbf{u}, respectively. For random slopes, each element of ğ™\mathbf{Z} equals the value of an auxiliary variable, ğ¤\mathbf{k}, if the observation is in the appropriate level of the random effect and zero otherwise.
